contextId.information: Paul speaks of "the life" as if it is an object inside of Jesus. This refers to the life people receive as a result of belonging to Christ. AT: "of the life that we receive as a result of belonging to Christ" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: of the life that is in Christ Jesus

contextId.information: Paul speaks of his conscience as if it could be physically clean. This means that a person does not feel guilty because he has always tried to do what was right. AT: "knowing I have tried my hardest to do what is right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: with a clean conscience

contextId.information: Paul speaks of himself as if he were a container that someone could fill. This can be stated in active form. AT: "I may be full of joy" or "I may have complete joy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: I may be filled with joy

contextId.information: Paul speaks about Timothy's need to start using his gift again as if he were restarting a fire. AT: "to start using again the gift" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to rekindle the gift

contextId.information: Paul speaks of suffering as if it were an object that could be shared or distributed among people. AT: "suffer with me for the gospel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: share in suffering for the gospel

contextId.information: Paul speaks of salvation as if it were an object that could uncovered and shown to people. This can be stated in active form. AT: "God has shown how he will save us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: God's salvation has been revealed

contextId.information: Paul speaks of death as if it were an independent process instead of the event of  people dying. AT: "who destroyed death" or "who made it possible for people not to remain dead forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: who put an end to death

contextId.information: Paul is using a metaphor of a person leaving something with another person who is supposed to protect it until he gives it back to the first person. Possible meanings are 1) Paul is trusting Jesus to help him remain faithful, or 2) Paul is trusting that Jesus will ensure that people continue spreading the gospel message. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to keep that which I have entrusted to him

contextId.information: Paul speaks of their ceasing to help him as if they had physically turned away from him. They abandoned Paul because the authorities had thrown him into prison. AT: "have stopped helping me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: turned away from me

contextId.information: Paul speaks of mercy as if it were an object that could be found. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to find mercy from him

contextId.information: Paul considered Timothy to be his son since he taught Timothy to trust in Christ. AT: "who is like my child" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my child

contextId.information: Paul speaks about the motivation and determination that God's grace allows believers to have. AT: "let God use the grace he gave you through your relationship to Christ Jesus to make you strong" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: be strengthened in the grace that is in Christ Jesus

contextId.information: Paul speaks of his instructions to Timothy as if they were objects that Timothy could give to other people and trust them to use correctly. AT: "commit them" or "teach them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: entrust them to faithful people

contextId.information: Paul speaks of this distraction as if it were a net that tripped people up as they were walking. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: while entangled

contextId.information: This is the third metaphor Paul gives Timothy about working. The reader should understand that Christ's servants need to work hard. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: It is necessary that the hardworking farmer receive his share of the crops first

contextId.information: Here "seed" means a descendant. AT: "who is a descendant of David" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: from David's seed

contextId.information: Paul speaks of salvation as if it were an object that could be physically grasped. AT: "will receive salvation from Christ Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: may obtain the salvation that is in Christ Jesus

contextId.information: Paul speaks of God's awareness of Paul as if he is in God's physical presence. This implies that God will be Timothy's witness. AT: "in God's presence" or "with God as your witness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: before God

contextId.information: The image is of the destruction of a building. Those who hear the quarreling stop respecting the Christian message. Their faith is destroyed. AT: "This only destroys the faith of those who listen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Because of this there is destruction for those who listen

contextId.information: Paul speaks of this kind of talk as if it were something that could physically move to another location, and he speaks of godlessness as if it were that new location. AT: "which causes people to become more and more ungodly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: which leads to more and more godlessness

contextId.information: Paul speaks of truth as if it were a target to aim at. Paul means that these men have not understood the truth and are teaching something false. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: missed the truth

contextId.information: Paul speaks of the destruction of people's faith as if their faith were physically overturned. AT: "They destroy the faith of some people" or "They cause some people to stop believing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They overturn the faith of some

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) "God's truth is like a firm foundation" or 2) "God has established his people like a building on a firm foundation" or 3) "God's faithfulness is like a firm foundation." In any case, Paul speaks of this idea as if it were a building's foundation laid in the ground. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the firm foundation of God stands

contextId.information: Paul speaks of unrighteousness as if it were a place from which one could leave. AT: "stop being evil" or "stop doing wrong things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: depart from unrighteousness

contextId.information: Here "container" is a general word for bowls, plates, and pots, which people put food or drink into or on. If your language does not have a general word, use the word for "bowl" or "pot." Paul is using this as a metaphor to describe different types of people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: containers of gold and silver ... containers of wood and clay

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) "separates himself from dishonorable people" or 2) "makes himself pure." In any case, Paul speaks of this process as if it were a person washing himself.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: cleans himself from dishonorable use

contextId.information: Paul speaks about this person as if he were an honorable container. AT: "he is like the container that is useful for special occasions" or "he is like the container that is useful for activities good people do in public" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he is an honorable container

contextId.information: He is not set apart physically or in the sense of location, but instead to fulfill a purpose. Some versions translate this "sanctified," but the text signals the essential idea of being set apart. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He is set apart

contextId.information: Paul speaks about youthful lusts as if they are a dangerous person or animal that Timothy should run away from. AT: "Completely avoid youthful lusts" or "Absolutely refuse to do the wrong things that young people strongly desire to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Flee youthful lusts

contextId.information: Paul speaks of someone's reason for calling on God as if it were in physical motion, emerging from his heart. AT: "with sincere motives" or "for good reasons" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: out of a clean heart

contextId.information: Paul speaks of repentance as if it were an object that God could give people. AT: "God may give them the opportunity to repent" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: God may perhaps give them repentance

contextId.information: Paul speaks of sinners learning to think correctly about God as if they were drunk people becoming sober again. AT: "They may think correctly again" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They may become sober again

contextId.information: Paul speaks of the devil when he convinces Christians to sin as if the devil had physically captured them and made them his slaves. This can be stated in active form. AT: "after he has deceived them into obeying his will" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: after they have been captured by him for his will

contextId.information: Paul speaks of godliness, the habit of honoring God, as if it were a physical object that had a shape.  AT: "appear godly" or "appear to honor God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: have a shape of godliness

contextId.information: Paul speaks of godliness as if it were a object that had physical power. Possible meanings are 1) "they will refuse to accept the power that God truly wants to give them" (UDB) or 2) "their lives will show no evidence of the godliness they say they have." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they will deny its power

contextId.information: Paul speaks of the attraction of sin as if sin were heaped up on the backs of these women. Possible meanings are 1) "who sin often" or 2) "who feel terrible guilt because they continue to sin." The idea is that these men can easily influence these women because the women are unable to stop sinning. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: who are heaped up with sins

contextId.information: Paul uses an expression about physical movement to mean that the false teachers will not have much success among the believers. AT: "they will not have much success" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they will not advance very far

contextId.information: Paul speaks of biblical instruction as if it were a place that Timothy could stay in. AT: "do not forget what you learned" or "continue doing what you have learned" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: remain in the things that you have learned

contextId.information: Paul speaks of people obtaining many teachers as if it were putting them into a heap or pile. AT: "they will listen to many teachers who assure them that there is nothing wrong with their sinful desires" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they will heap up for themselves teachers according to their own desires

contextId.information: Paul speaks about people no longer paying attention as if they were physically turning away so they cannot hear. AT: "They will no longer pay attention to the truth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They will turn their hearing away from the truth

contextId.information: Paul wants his readers to think correctly about everything, and he speaks about them as if he wanted them to be sober, that is, not drunk with wine. AT: "think clearly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: be sober-minded

contextId.information: Paul speaks of his readiness to die as if he were a cup of wine ready to be poured out as a sacrifice to God.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I am already being poured out

contextId.information: Paul speaks of his hard work as if he had been an athlete competing for a prize. AT: "I have done my best" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I have competed in the good contest

contextId.information: Paul speaks of his trust in Christ and his obedience to God as if they were a valuable object that he kept in his possession. Possible meanings are 1) "I have been faithful in doing my ministry" (UDB) or 2) "I have kept the teachings about what we believe from any error" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I have kept the faith

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) the crown is the prize that God gives to people who have lived the right way (UDB) or 2) the crown is a metaphor for righteousness. Just as the judge of a race gives a crown to the winner, when Paul finishes his life, God will declare that Paul is righteous. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: crown of righteousness

contextId.information: Paul speaks of doing evil deeds as if they were put on display. AT: "did many evil things to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: displayed many evil deeds against me

contextId.information: Paul is speaking as if the Lord had physically stood with him. AT: "the Lord helped me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the Lord stood by me

contextId.information: Paul is speaking about danger as if he had been threatened by a lion. This danger could have been physical, spiritual, or both. AT: "I was rescued from great danger" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I was rescued out of the lion's mouth
